[{'id': 41, 'article_title': 'NATAL.', 'full_section_title': 'NATAL.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_11_1862#article-20', 'issue_date': '22_11_1862', 'content': 'The select committee of this last session made a report, which, whilst approving of land being at once set apart adequate for the natives, provided it was invested solely in the Lieutenant-Governor for the time being, as their supreme chief, condemned the Government scheme which contemplated some thirty chiefs to be joint trustees, and urged the granting of individual titles as soon as practicable, under suitable restrictions as regards their alienation. The result is that the Governor has accepted the trust, subject to Her Majesty's approval, to enable his Excellency to carry out the objects of which, and appoint the officers necessary to carry out the trust under his directions, and the Council have pledged themselves to vote the means. The colony is thus saved from the much-dreaded establishment of an *imperium in imperio*, with all its attendant evils, and it now only remains for the Executive to carry out in good faith the conditions of the trust they have accepted. What the Imperial Government regards as "adequate" is such land as would make persistent industry necessary on the part of the blacks, whilst the policy of the local authorities would seem to be to give to all blacks who like to come enough for their conditions and pursuits, and something more.

In one of our previous letters we alluded to the great dissatisfaction felt in the colony at the Lieutenant-Governor's despatches (which had been published) to his Grace the Secretary of State for the Colonies. The following are the concluding paragraphs of the Report of a Select Committee of the Legislative Council on this subject. We do not know how his Excellency the Lieutenant-Governor feels under such reproof, but no one can accuse our Natal fellow-citizens of a too patient endurance of wrong at the hands of "those who are appointed to rule over them":—'}, {'id': 178, 'article_title': 'NATAL.', 'full_section_title': 'NATAL.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1863#article-11', 'issue_date': '23_06_1863', 'content': 'By the Cape Mail we have news from Natal to the 3rd April. Previous reports are confirmed as regards the harvest prospects in this most interesting and important colony. Never, it is said, has there before been such a growing season. Never before did the crops look so green, advanced, and promising in March and April. All this is owing to a steady succession of genial rainfalls. The crop of Sugar is expected to be very large. This is very important for the colony, because Natal sugar has now become a favourite in the Australian markets. Coffee, Cotton, and all other products, look most promising, and a generally good yield is anticipated. Cotton, Flax, and other textile fabrics, are occupying attention in the colony. The average yield of Sea Island cotton will, it is said, be about 400lbs. of ginned cotton per acre. It is also now affirmed that cotton planting and sugar planting may be carried on successfully together, because at the time when labour is most wanted in the cotton fields it is least needed in the cane fields. Several patches of cotton, of a few acres each, are to be seen this year. But unless the Kafirs take to labour in the cotton fields, the labour question will be the great difficulty. The Flax that has been experimentally grown has given abundant yield, and the quality is reported as "very good." Wool is to become the favourite product of the upper country. There are continual importations of Sheep from the Cape, and of Rams of good breed from Australia and England. Some Alpacas are also expected from Australia. It is thought they are peculiarly suited to the hill pastures of Natal, and will give value to some of the wild kloofs of the country. Coffee planting is making steady progress. Coffee pays remarkably well, and its cultivation is therefore certain to be increased.

The Colonial-office in Downing-street has disallowed the bill passed last session for raising the Governor's salary from 1,200l. to 3,000l. a-year.

**Zambesi.**—An expedition on an extensive scale has left the Natal borders for the Zambesi. Waggons had been built specially for the purpose. The object is said to be sport. Other similar expeditions are likely to follow. The eldest son of Dr. Livingstone had arrived at Natal, from Glasgow, en route, to join his father at Quillimane.

**Gold.**—Some Australian and Californian gold-diggers have been exploring the quartz districts. Indications of gold were found; but their labours were not rewarded by the discovery of any nuggets.

**Kafir Wealth.**—At a grand Kafir wedding, the bride-cake cost 10l.'}, {'id': 224, 'article_title': 'LAGOS, SEPT. 9.', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS, SEPT. 9.', 'last_edit_date': '09-09-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1863#article-12', 'issue_date': '23_10_1863', 'content': 'The Governor has decreed the formation of a town on British territory, opposite Epé, famous for Mr. Freeman's expedition, in which Major Leveson was wounded. He offers land in this township of Oko-Tapa to our merchants, for trading purposes only, at 3l. per acre. We all approve of the attempt to establish this town, which, if successful, will lead to increased communications with the interior of Yoruba by other route than that of Abeokuta. But is not this very decree of a town opposite Epé, on British territory, a strong condemnation of Governor Freeman's expedition, in which so many lives were wantonly cast away? I look at it as being so, and think you will do the same.

We are trying further experiments in taxation, and I shall be
**45**

curious to hear what you think about some of them. For instance, merchants who import and sell rum, &c., are to pay a licence of 50l. per annum; and all petty traders of every class a licence of 1l. per annum. Opinion is very much divided here on the subject. One result is certain, there will be no small importers of spirits.

I will tell you why this has been done. We are creating a great many paid offices here—money must be had for them—and the magnificent rum and tobacco duties, which were to yield 20,000l. a-year, will now, it is thought, produce not more than 5,000l., because traders will be such asses! as to go to Porto Novo, where there are no duties, in preference to paying heavy ones here. So in order, if possible, to prevent their carrying on a spirit business both here and at Porto Novo, they are to be enticed to give up the latter by a new exaction of 50l. per annum in addition to the said duties! Funny inducement, is it not? It is a pity we are not educated up to the point at which we might be able fully to comprehend the masterly policy of our talented rulers.

Our trading condition may be stated in three words—as we were. No arrangement yet with Abeokuta, and, in consequence, merchants suffering dreadfully.

One result of the friendly intercourse between the French Admiral, &c., and our Governor and merchants, mentioned in my last, is, that the boundaries of the respective French and English territories (for so they must now be called) around Porto Novo are likely to be at once settled.

Lieut.-Commander Moultrie has taken the command of H.M.'s ship Handy.

We are anxious to know whether Mr. Freeman is to come out again as Governor. A memorial has been got up here in favour of Captain Glover as Governor, greatly, I believe, to the captain's regret. But I scarcely need to tell you that the zeal of some persons is greater than their discretion. I hope our Acting Governor will not have cause to say, "Heaven preserve me from my (so-called) friends!"

Yours, &c.,'}, {'id': 681, 'article_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-0', 'issue_date': '23_09_1865', 'content': "The only Governor who saw the advantage of enlisting our influence was Sir Benjamin Pine, who, to the utter amazement of the friends of the old system, showed us a very warm friendship, and heard our advice, as he knew he could depend upon our reports. Had he remained longer on the Coast, he would have greatly developed our country. But his successors undid what he had done, his own brother included.

You will remember that Lieutenant Sealer, when he was Acting Chief Civil Commandant, went up hither to settle the palavers which arose in consequence of the people's superstition about the small-pox, which he did in a very clever way. Well, when Captain Edmunds returned, poor Sealey had to pay the whole cost of this expedition, to the amount of about 18l., out of his own pocket! And this was one of the wise acts of our dear Pine, who is lamenting that he is one of the most ill-used innocents in existence!

Still, our work, thanks be to our Lord, is growing fast. The old fetishism is showing everywhere that they feel that the end is approaching, and they prepare for the last struggle. But the victory must belong to Christ, and him even crucified! Glory be to Him for ever!—Believe me, faithfully yours,  
C. L.

---

**DAHOMEY.**

**TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.**

Great Popo, July 29.

Dear Sir,—Being away down here on business, I have not been a witness of the last great custom for the late King, which you will have heard a month or two ago was about to be held for building the blood-house over his grave. We hear that the mud being used for building this monument is mixed with human blood and liquors instead of water. The greater portion of the prisoners made by the King from the five towns he took on his late expedition will be sacrificed for this purpose.

There is no demand for slaves for exportation now. The slave merchants who had collected a number for shipment are now selling them back to the natives, to work on their plantations. This point, at least, has been gained. But it is a great pity we cannot get some parties, with a little capital, and with knowledge, to settle here, and instruct the natives in raising other produce, in addition to, or instead of, palm oil. It would be, indeed, a great blessing to this Coast.

A French vessel loading palm kernels was lately driven ashore here. She became a total wreck, and has been left to be plundered by the natives.—Yours, truly,  
J.

---"}, {'id': 800, 'article_title': 'Gold Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Gold Coast', 'last_edit_date': '03-09-1866', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1866#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_04_1866', 'content': "The present movements by the Governor, &c., against the Awoonahs may serve to throw some light on the course of policy entered upon by the Government since the Ashantee war; I mean as regards the practicability of effective British rule in these countries with such a policy. Thousands of natives are now collecting in arms for an expedition, in which, as it at present seems, the Government is not to furnish any subsistence, but merely confine its supplies to munitions of war. But subsistence these native troops must have, and if not regularly supplied, will it not be levied in the shape of plunder? There is some talk of the merchants furnishing subsistence, but it would then remain to be seen whether they could or would meet all just demands, or continue willingly to do so should the affair be a protracted one. Would it not have been better for the Government to provide subsistence from a fund to which the merchants should have subscribed, compelling the Awoonahs to pay it? The new policy of the Home Government places a Governor here now in positions of great difficulty, and many look with some anxiety for the results. Colonel Conran's determination and energy may enable him to succeed, notwithstanding those difficulties created by the Government policy, which he is, of course, expected to carry out as far as possible; but if he succeeds, it will be in spite of, not as a consequence of that Government policy.—Yours,"}, {'id': 913, 'article_title': 'ANAMABOE', 'full_section_title': 'ANAMABOE', 'last_edit_date': '07-11-1866', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_09_1866#article-4', 'issue_date': '22_09_1866', 'content': "Sir,—I cannot conceal from you my apprehension that the new system of Government policy for the Protected Territories will lead to all sorts of confusion and trouble, and prove eminently disastrous for these countries. If Government cannot do anything for us, why are we to pay duties? If no soldiers are to be moved from the forts for any service, why should any duties be paid, except at Cape Coast, where they are stationed? There may be some reason for Cape Coast Town paying duties, because Colonel Conran, who is a good fellow for this, has taken a great deal of trouble in clearing all the rubbish from the town, and putting the streets in order; but in the way things now go, we do not think he is good as a governor for anything else besides this. You have said in your paper that the Ashantee peace has been made, but there is nothing of the kind, I am sorry to say. I write this to you though people say that you will not put anything in your paper against Colonel Conran, but I don't believe this. Why, look at Anamaboe Fort. All here is left under one man, Mr. ——. I am sure you will say that it's no good government to leave all authority in the hands of such a man as this Mr. ——, who buys and keeps domestic slaves, and has quite a harem of slave women at his house? Is such a man as this fit to hold Her Majesty's commission as Justice of the Peace? I say no! And would a good governor let such a man hold the commission? I say no. And what sort of justice are we likely to get from such a Justice of the Peace? I say, none at all.—Your obedient servant, F."}, {'id': 914, 'article_title': "Administration of Justice at Cape Coast. Stipendiary Magistrates' Court.", 'full_section_title': "Administration of Justice at Cape Coast. Stipendiary Magistrates' Court.", 'last_edit_date': '08-11-1866', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_09_1866#article-5', 'issue_date': '22_09_1866', 'content': 'Sir,—There has been a great row in the Stipendiary Magistrates' Court. Mr. Oakes, P.M.O. of the 2nd West India Regiment, summoned Mr. W. C. Finlason for twelve guineas for medical visits. Mr. Finlason pleaded that he was only indebted six guineas. Captain Hall, 2nd West India Regiment also, sat as stipendiary magistrate. He came into court arm-in-arm with his friend Mr. Oakes, the plaintiff, who sat on the bench with him. Mr. Oakes stated his case, but called no witnesses. The defendant called evidence to establish that Mr. Oakes only attended him _five times._ The magistrate's examination of the witnesses, one in particular, was very severe. The defendant then addressed the Bench, and, among other things, said "he knew how the case must end," upon which Captain Hall attacked him very violently, charging him with having imputed to him something dishonourable. The defendant apologised if he had said anything disrespectful, such not being his intention, and stated that what he meant was that Captain Hall must necessarily, after the evidence, decide in his (the defendant's) favour. The magistrate stopped him, saying "he did not believe a word," and that, in a previous case, when the defendant was acting _as an advocate,_ he uttered a _gross falsehood_ to the chief justice. The defendant, considering himself insulted, sat down. On leaving the court, a few minutes after, in a great rage, as might naturally be expected, he asked a native gentleman, also an advocate in the courts, whether the latter did not consider that he had been grossly insulted, to which the reply was: "Yes, he is a blackguard—a mean, low blackguard to take such an advantage of you," which met, of course, with acquiescence. Captain Hall, the magistrate, _was not then in court,_ but in the Fort; a bystander, however, carried to him information of what had been said. Accordingly, on the following Monday, Judge Hackett, sitting in the Supreme Court, called upon Mr. Finlason to explain, which he did, to the effect that whatever he might have said was " _out of court_"—that he had received a most unwarranted and unprecedented insult from the Bench—hence was in a great rage out of court, and might possibly have made use of such words, for which, however, if he had so done, he was sorry, and hoped that Captain Hall would also make the _amende honorable_ to him. This Captain Hall did not do. Upon which the native advocate before-mentioned got up'}, {'id': 1038, 'article_title': 'Dogberry Justice (Not from Shakespeare)', 'full_section_title': 'Dogberry Justice (Not from Shakespeare)', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1867#article-6', 'issue_date': '23_02_1867', 'content': 'Defendant: I beg your worship's pardon. You did fine that man in the amount of a day's labour, besides condemning him in costs.

Magistrate: I did not fine him. I particularly avoided using the word fine. Did you hear me say that I fine that man, Mr. Metzger?

Metzger (Police Clerk): No, Sir; you made an order.

Defendant: As your worship says you did not fine the man, will you be good enough to let me know what you did do—what was your decision in the case?

Magistrate (throwing himself back, and with great emphasis),
**91**

"Yes, I will tell what I did do. I condemned him in costs and 'mulcted' him the amount of a day's labour."

The Police Clerk bowed assent.

Defendant: Well, I was not aware that there was any difference between fining and mulcting.

Magistrate: O, yes, there is a legal difference; so you see that ordinance does not apply.

Defendant: I submit that, even if, as you say, you mulcted the plaintiff, and did not fine him, still he is disabled from recovering any money, if it were even due to him, by this ordinance, because he was condemned in costs by you, and, as you say, mulcted besides, and this was convicting him of refusal and neglect of duty.

Magistrate: I say that the ordinance does not apply, and you very well know that. You are so much in the habit of misrepresenting the truth that when it is put plainly before you you can't see it. You know that I never fined that man, and you merely misrepresented what I did so as to misrepresent this ordinance, and make it apply, although you know very well that it does not apply. I will not have you to distort the truth here in this manner.

Defendant: I did not know that you never fined that man, nor do I know that the ordinance does not apply. I submit that it still applies, and I must say in my own defence that I do not think it fair, nor do I think that you have any right to sit there on that bench and grossly insult me in this way, by telling me that I habitually misrepresent truth, that I "know" the ordinance does not apply, and that I have misrepresented you so that I should apply it; in short, telling me, in so many words, I am a liar. I am the same professional man as you, and am equally bound to defend my character.

Magistrate: You a professional man?

Defendant: Yes, the same as you, of a different profession, but still a professional man.

Magistrate: Well, let me tell you that you are not on a level with me in any respect.

Defendant: That is a matter of opinion.

Magistrate: And I must inform you that I will not have you to be addressing me here in that manner.

Defendant: I am bound in defence of my character to address you in the manner I have addressed you, when you sit there and in so many words call me a liar.

Magistrate: Very well. Now, as you would not shut your mouth, and let me settle the case as I was going to settle it, I will show you that you shall pay this man; I will make you pay him.'}, {'id': 1065, 'article_title': 'SIERRA LEONE', 'full_section_title': 'SIERRA LEONE', 'last_edit_date': '03-17-1867', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1867#article-2', 'issue_date': '23_04_1867', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—We have been very quiet here of late, with the exception of the unmistakable expression of public opinion about saddling the colony with the expenses of those appeals in which Mr. Shaw, &c., have been defeated in England, by the adverse judgments of the Privy Council. The Governor-General has been absent, having been on a voyage to Goree, the Gambia, Bulama, &c. The state of public feeling about the "Shaw's costs" business is very well shown in the following extract from the *African Interpreter* of yesterday:—

"An exhibition of public feeling was dexterously avoided by Governor Blackall's Councillors a few weeks ago. It seems that his Excellency, whether, in his own language, he thought the business too 'nasty' for him to perform which was contemplated to be done in Council—viz., an attempt to saddle the colony with the enormous costs of Mr. Collector Shaw's official ignorance and his advisers—or whether more urgent business called him away, left in the colonial steamer for Gambia, appointing as President of the Council during his absence Mr. Huggins, the Acting Chief Justice. Mr. Shaw went along with his Excellency, and some days after a meeting of the Legislative Council was called, at which of course President Huggins presided. Nothing of greater importance characterized this meeting than the rumour that somehow or other it was contemplated at the next meeting to propose that the expenses incurred by Mr. Shaw should be defrayed at the expense of the public. But this was enough. The rumour flew, and with its spread higher and higher rose the indignation of the people. If Governor Blackall had been here then, possibly he would have had a deputation, including every taxpayer in the colony, waiting upon him or obstructing the entrances at Fort Thornton. There was no mistaking the alarming seriousness and determination on almost every countenance of the great body of taxpayers. Pay who might, they were resolved, with every constitutional means in their power, to resist an imposition upon them of Mr. Shaw's most unjustifiably incurred expenses. But the Acting Chief Justice would not run the risk of hazarding the proposal, and on the next day of meeting adjourned the Council *sine die*."

But his Excellency returned, and we have had our regatta, at which Commodore Hornby was also present; and more than this, yesterday afternoon, Saturday (the mail goes to England to-day, Sunday), Governor Blackall called a Council, and *himself* moved a resolution *that Mr. Shaw's expenses should be saddled on the colony.* The Acting Chief Justice seconded it; Mr. Pike, one of Shaw's bondsmen, of course voted for it, as equally of course did Captain, Judge, and Magistrate Bravo, and Mr. Huggins, the Queen's Advocate, who advised the seizures which the Privy Council have condemned.'}, {'id': 1390, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST AFFAIRS.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST AFFAIRS.', 'last_edit_date': '08-07-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-8', 'issue_date': '23_09_1868', 'content': "Sir,—You will learn by this that Mr. Ussher, the Administrator of these settlements, is going to England by this mail steamer. He shipped himself off this afternoon at four o'clock, on board the Pandora, one of Her Majesty's war ships recently stationed here for the use of the Administrator, to await the arrival of the mail steamer to-morrow. The Ashantee messengers have been sent away, and ere this time they will have arrived in Ashantee.

Elmina and Fantee affairs remain the same as I wrote you last; there has been no movement of any kind. The meetings of the Fantee kings and chiefs at Mankassim has broken up. They will meet again after their Yam Custom, which latter takes place the middle of next month. The Elminas have applied to their Governor for a loan of money to assist them in preparing against the expected attack from the Fantees, and having obtained the loan (I am not sure of the amount, but some say 200 ounces of gold) have sent to the Windward Coast and allied themselves to some of the tribes there, who are also Dutch subjects, to come to their help whenever the Fantees are about to march against them. The Elminas are still suffering from want of food. Since the Fantee camp broke up the Elminas generally get their supplies from here. Their bush-people who work in farms are still in the town, and unable to return to their croons, fearing that they would be made captives of by the Fantees—several of them who did venture had been caught and made prisoners already.

Mr. Simpson, the Collector-General, who will be sworn in tomorrow noon as the Acting-Administrator, seems to be a more experienced man; and I heard it said yesterday that he will adopt a different system to what his predecessor did, meaning that he will govern the people mildly, and let them have their innocent amusements, as they had hitherto been deprived of by both Conran and Ussher.

The proposed treaty between the Elminas and Fantees was knocked on the head. The Fantees said they never proposed any such thing, and for that reason they will never sign the treaty, which compromises their honour. Some of the parties have admitted that they acted contrary to the instructions of the chiefs, as they never commissioned anyone to proceed up to Elmina and propose peace, more especially with such terms and provisions as were in the treaty. No sooner did their refusal to sign the treaty reach Mr. Ussher, than he wrote to the chiefs that Her Majesty's Government does not acknowledge them any longer, and in future they are not to expect any help from that Government. You shall soon have all the correspondence on these matters.—Believe me yours very truly,  
**Fantee.**

P.S. Doctor Jones advised Mr. Ussher to go to England, owing to his delicate health. Doctor Jones will receive 300l. per annum as Acting-Collector-General, in the place of Mr. Simpson, while the Administrator is away."}, {'id': 1479, 'article_title': 'FINLASON v. RICHTER, THE GAOLER.', 'full_section_title': 'FINLASON v. RICHTER, THE GAOLER.', 'last_edit_date': '11-16-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1868#article-6', 'issue_date': '23_12_1868', 'content': "It will, doubtless, not have escaped your memory that Vine, the policeman, gave evidence at the trial fully substantiating the charges I brought against Richter. This appears to have given offence to Chief Magistrate Parker, who ordered poor Vine to be imprisoned on a charge of perjury. After being kept in prison six weeks, poor Vine was released by order of the Acting Commandant here, Captain Russell, no prosecution having been instituted against him.

Is this justice? Surely Her Majesty's Government at home must be aware of the continued outrages that justice is receiving at the hands of Mr. W. A. Parker, and the contempt into which it is brought by him. Look at my own case and that of the Bannermans, Hesse, Dodoo, Mrs. Ansah's pet dog, &c., &c.

By the regular mail I will forward you a certified copy of the proceedings had in my case against Richter, with the sentence of Capt. Russell; the Commandant; and then it is to be hoped, for the sake of justice and truth, that his Grace the Secretary of State will see the urgent necessity of taking some effective means of putting an end to a method of administering so-called justice that has greatly assisted in destroying British prestige in these parts.—Yours truly,

**Wm. Chas. Finlason.**

---

**SHIP NEWS.**

*Cape Coast, 9th October to 8th November.*

**ARRIVALS.**—James Duckett, Oct. 9; Mary Campbell, Oct. 9; Roebuck, Oct. 11; Albertina, Oct. 12; Axim, Oct. 14; Sea Sprite, Oct. 15; R.M.S. Lagos, Oct. 16; Dromo, Oct. 17; Venus, Oct. 19; Warren White, Oct. 19; Mary Evans, Oct. 21; Sea Sprite, Oct. 23; H.M.S. Lee, Oct. 27, with his Excellency the Governor-in-Chief; French Frigate Bellone, Oct. 28, with French Admiral; Mischief, Oct. 28; R.M.S. Calabar, Oct. 29; R.M.S. Lagos, Nov. 8.

**DEPARTURES.**—James Duckett, Oct. 9, for Leewards; Mary Campbell, Oct. 13, for Leewards; Roebuck, Oct. 17, for Leewards; Albertina, Oct. 29, for Leewards; Axim, Oct. 19, for Leewards; Sea Sprite, Oct. 17, for Leewards; R.M.S. Lagos, Oct. 29, for Leewards; Dromo, Oct. 22, for Leewards; Venus, Oct. 30, for Leewards; Warren White, Oct. 23, for Leewards; Mary Evans, Oct. 22, for Leewards; Sea Sprite, Oct. 25, for Windward; French Frigate Bellone, Oct. 30, for Leewards; Mischief, Oct. 30, for Salt Pond to fill up; R.M.S. Calabar, Oct. 29, for Leewards; R.M.S. Lagos, Nov. 8, with mails for Europe.

N.B.—Governor-General Kennedy still at Cape Coast, endeavouring to settle disputes between Elminas and the Fantees. Trade very dull indeed; place healthy; gin the only article in great demand.

---"}, {'id': 1529, 'article_title': 'Gross Outrage by Administrator Glover', 'full_section_title': 'Gross Outrage by Administrator Glover', 'last_edit_date': '04-23-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1869#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_04_1869', 'content': 'About one o'clock in the morning Dr. Simpson, Colonial Surgeon, brought our release; he and Captain Méyer having bailed us out. We were then obliged to walk back with our clothes completely wet with dew, and arrived at home about two o'clock A.M.

The next morning we appeared before the police magistrate, Mr. J. Gerard, lieutenant in the 2nd West India Regiment, who, immediately he came into court, dismissed Captain Rascher, and said it was all a mistake bringing him there at all. Mr. J. Gerard, the police magistrate, then went into evidence against deponent, upon which he remanded the case until the following Monday, when deponent appeared again, and the said police magistrate discharged deponent in about the following words—viz.: "I have conferred with the Chief Magistrate, who confirms my own ideas that you were decidedly in the wrong in sending such a message to the Governor; but I dismiss the case, and hope it will not occur again." Deponent then left the Court.

Immediately on arrival at home, deponent wrote the following letter to his Excellency Captain Glover, dated the 22nd February, 1869:—

"Sir,—I have to demand from you an ample apology in writing for the gross outrage committed on myself by you and your men on Friday evening last, together with the sum of fifty pounds sterling, to be given to some local charity or charities of my naming. Should these demands not be forthcoming on or before the first day of March prox., I shall instruct my solicitor to commence legal proceedings against you elsewhere. Waiting your prompt reply, I am, Sir, your obedient servant."

To this letter deponent has received no reply. On the 24th day of February, 1869, deponent addressed the following letters to his Honour Benjamin Way, Chief Magistrate of Lagos—viz.:—

"Sir,—I have the honour to request that you will inform me whether any warrant was issued against me on the night of the 19th instant, and if so I beg respectfully that you will furnish me with a copy of the said warrant, together with a certified copy of the sworn information which led to its being issued against me.

"I am prepared to pay the usual fee for those documents.—I have the honour to be, Sir, your most obedient servant,

"W. D. T."

To this letter deponent has also received no reply. On the 25th February, 1869, deponent wrote as follows to Sigis Rasmus:

[APRIL 23, 1869

Wilkey and John A. Payne, Esq., both Clerks of the Court at Lagos:—

"I have the honour to request that you will be good enough to inform me whether any warrant was issued against me on Friday night last, and if so I beg that you will furnish me with a certified copy of the same, together with the sworn information which led to me being arrested and ironed on the night above named.

"I am prepared to pay the usual office-fee for those documents.—I have the honour to be, Sir, your obedient servant,

"W. D. T."'}, {'id': 1642, 'article_title': 'Memorial to His Royal Highness Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh', 'full_section_title': 'Memorial to His Royal Highness Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh', 'last_edit_date': '07-03-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1869#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_09_1869', 'content': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Supreme Court, Sierra Leone, July 3, 1869.

Sir,—It has been said that zeal in the commencement of any undertaking and apathy in its final execution marks an ill-regulated and badly-balanced mind. What is true of an individual is applicable to a nation, who are but assembled individuals; and when I contrast the desire we once felt to raise some memorial to our sailor prince, and the apathy in the completion of the work which we have too long delayed, I think that we have exhibited ill-regulated and badly-balanced minds. This distinguished Prince, following out the counsels of one of the greatest authorities of antiquity, has visited all regions of the earth, and wherever he went, by the frank and unassuming dignity of his manner, has won golden opinions from all classes of men. It is well known in England how dear he is to the heart of his royal mother; and when he escaped the assassin's bullet in Australia (a blessed fact to be engraven for all ages on our future memorials), the exclamation of his brother—England's future king—showed how dear he was to him: "Oh, my God! poor Alfred; what will my poor mother say?"—sweet domestic words, showing how, in a palace, children reared after England's old fashion (a dear combination of head and heart) can exhibit the simple and unadorned virtues of the cottage. When the Prince, for the first time after the base attempt upon his life, appeared at the Crystal Palace in England, the whole immense audience rose, and the musical strains of fifty bands were drowned in the tumultuous music of the heart, poured forth by 50,000 enraptured beings.

Art opens to us here at Sierra Leone a lasting power to exhibit our joy. The transient emotions of the heart pass away, however potent they may be, but in the painter and sculptor are reserved the power of fixity for all ages. To us the opportunity is not given to secure the services of the great historians of thought; but a graceful and classical column, rendered still more graceful by inscribing the simple record of the life of our sailor prince, we can at least command. Let us at least redeem the scandal and public scorn entailed by ex-Governor Blackall's mock exhibition, and let his imaginary tenants in buckram make way for a right royal Prince in the fullness of flesh and blood. I shall not abandon this deeply interesting question, and at a future, but not distant, period entering more into detail, I shall respectfully suggest the site for the memorial, the inscription it should bear, and the ceremonies which should be adopted when it is revealed to public view by one who so worthily represents the illustrious mother of the Prince in his rule over at length happy Africa.

In a subsequent communication I will inquire into some circumstances connected with the subscription raised for erecting this memorial, and show the disaster which resulted from the...
[SEPTEMBER 23, 1869.]

---'}, {'id': 2136, 'article_title': 'SMALL-POX AT CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'SMALL-POX AT CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '11-30-1871', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1872#article-16', 'issue_date': '23_01_1872', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—Dr. Mosse has responded to the article in the last _African Times_ treating on the introduction of small-pox into this place, and with reference to his reply, there are two matters to which I would particularly draw your attention.

1st. If proper precautions were taken, how came the hospital servant, Quashie Hajan, and a woman and daughter in Gothic House, to catch the disease? The poor woman and daughter died on the same day, a few hours only intervening between the two deaths.

2nd. The small-pox was never introduced here direct from the mail steamers; but was brought by the prisoner from Accra in May last on S.S. Biafra. We shall be glad if Dr. Mosse will refresh our memory as to when, and from what mail steamers this disease was introduced here direct.

Now a few words with reference to the address got up for Mr. Ussher when he was about to leave. You copied into your paper an article from a Cape Coast publication, exposing the state of Cape Coast Town, which was justly said to be one mass of filth—a veritable dung-hill; and you commented upon this in the _African Times_ in a way that stirred up official indignation at him whose article you thus copied in all quarters. To pacify them, he got up an address for Martyr Ussher. He had his own objects in view, of course; but not everybody followed the crafty lead, and I for one refused to sign. You cannot expose in too strong a language that system of addresses of sham praise. Pray continue to do your duty in a straightforward manner, without deference for colour, and God will reward you for your labours.

I hope you will not fail to let the Colonial-office know how, and with what object, that address given to Martyr Ussher was got up to pacify official displeasure.—Yours faithfully,'}, {'id': 2267, 'article_title': 'Claims for Compensation at Cape Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Claims for Compensation at Cape Coast', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1872#article-17', 'issue_date': '23_07_1872', 'content': "It seems to us there never was a clearer case for compensation than that of the late political prisoners at Cape Coast. Two memorials or petitions by them appear in our present number. One is from the members of the Fanti Confederation who were arbitrarily imprisoned, and subsequently held to heavy bail by Mr. Salmon, Acting Administrator of the Gold Coast, without any charge whatever being formalised against them, or any measures being subsequently taken to bring them to trial, for any alleged offence whatever. The other is from the two Fynns (sen. and jun.), and Forson, who were arbitrarily thrust into prison on most groundless charges, and who were acquitted by unanimous verdict of an educated jury when brought to trial, although every possible effort was made by the Executive and judicial authorities to force a conviction. No sooner had the arbitrary and wrongful acts above alluded to been committed, than we made a claim for compensation to the innocent sufferers. Such petitions as have been now forwarded by the Governor-in-Chief, cannot with any show of justice be left unattended to by the Secretary of State for the Colonies; and if attended to, compensation must, we think, follow. We think this because the official acts and utterances of the Governor-in-Chief show that the continuous statement of facts lodged by us at the Colonial-office between December, 1871, and the date of Mr. Pope Hennessy's departure for the West Coast, had proved to Her Majesty's Government that the Local Executive and judicial authorities at Cape Coast had fallen into grievous error, both in their treatment of the elected officers of the Fanti Confederation and also in that of the two Mr. Fynns and Mr. Forson. No one can ever justly accuse us of a desire to squander or fritter away the revenues of the West African Settlements. We most assuredly would never have sent out to Cape Coast such a steamer as the Nellie, of which doomed craft we make mention elsewhere. The objects to be achieved by an enlightened Executive at the Gold Coast, whenever that protectorate may be blessed with one, are of such vital importance if its countries are to be guided on to civilization, and will require so much money, that we should be the last to make a stroke of the pen in favour of any expenditure for other purposes, not absolutely called for by the claims of justice and equity, and for indispensable Executive and judicial wants. When, therefore, we say that we think compensation must be awarded by Her Majesty's Government to persons so much wronged, knowing, as we but too well do, that such compensation must come out of the local, and not out of imperial revenue, we feel sure that our readers will understand how very strong our convictions are of what justice and equity demand in these cases."}, {'id': 2394, 'article_title': "Classpeter and Sawyer's Case", 'full_section_title': "Classpeter and Sawyer's Case", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/28_02_1873#article-10', 'issue_date': '28_02_1873', 'content': "

This is what affects all natives of the interior. It is therefore they ask the Government to have the matter settled. The instructions given by Governor Pope Hennessy and Mr. Fowler were to induce the natives to open the roads, and that these two questions should be settled afterwards. In the meantime, if a woman came to Lagos, and her husband turned up, and she admitted him to be her husband, and that she was not a slave, and especially when she had borne him children, she should be sent back with her husband to save trouble; but if any slave came to Lagos he or she could not be sent back. In fact, even Capt. Glover used to send away wives with their husbands, after he returned from England in 1866, and so things went on smoothly; but later, when he had an object in view, he permitted his ragamuffin Ijayi and Yorubas friends to go and entice wives and slaves away, and took steamers into the rivers and creeks, to annoy the people, and make them the means of domestic slaves escaping from their masters. He must have known what all this would come to—destruction and ruin, as we see at this day. The King of Jebu and Government yielded to Governor Pope Hennessy's overtures, but between the 24th September and the 7th October last, Capt. Glover's party in Lagos used all the discharged V.R. Police as agencies for diffusing erroneous ideas among the Lagosians at Epe (who are their friends, and to whom Capt. Glover made large presents out of our revenue ere he was sent away), and making them instruments in telling the Jebus secretly that they have been deceived; that the Government will not carry out their promises; Turo used the Isheri people as instruments to sow suspicion in the hearts of the Egbas; that the Lagos Government are deceiving them, and that the Egbas should use their influence to persuade the Jebus to hold out and disbelieve any promises that had been made. Hence all the good that it was supposed had been done, has come to nothing. Notwithstanding these disappointments, we are not disheartened—we are doing our best. The enemies to peace and trade have done their worst to thwart our proceedings. Fancy, those erroneous statements of Mr. Charles Leigh Clare, of Manchester, were (at least, it is reasonable so to suppose) furnished to him through Capt. Glover by C. D. Turton (agent for Mr. Clare in Lagos), late Postmaster, who wrote them to assist Capt. Glover, so that he might be the Colonial Secretary, and J. H. Willoughby Tuvo, &c., have good employments. It happened that two women, wives of two Ikorodu men, were brought away to Lagos on the 28th July last; one of these had four children to her husband—the last child was on her back. The other woman had three children by her husband, but they died. The two husbands came after them the same day, and found out where they were. Next day, the women were taken to the Governor, and on inquiry they owned, that the two men are their husbands, and that they are their wives. King Docemo represented the matter too; and the Governor asked why they came away; they said on account of private family matters, which they related. The reasons were so frivolous that the Governor said they must go with their husbands; and they went with them."}, {'id': 2882, 'article_title': 'The Primitive Methodist Day-School at Fernando Po', 'full_section_title': 'The Primitive Methodist Day-School at Fernando Po', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1875#article-15', 'issue_date': '01_06_1875', 'content': '

be aware that we are surrounded by about forty or fifty heathen towns, and our Society expecting to civilize the whole of them; so he could see that there is room for him if he could only climb from a semi-civilized to a civilized state. In conclusion, let me fulfill the design of my writing by giving the public some information respecting the above-named school, and that briefly. This school was formed in September, 1870, and on March, 1871, I was engaged as a school and missionary assistant. When I went to the school I met A. M. Savage, who was afterwards stabbed here and died at Cape Coast Castle. We both conducted the school until the two years' examination mentioned by "Progress," which he states makes the people glad. That examination took place a year and four months from the establishment of the school (and that was two years according to "Progress's" reckoning). After that examination, his Excellency of 1872 proclaimed that all the children in Santa Isabel must be sent to the Spanish day-school which he proposed to form, which, as far as every one did prove, was not satisfactory to the people here; but heavy fine and imprisonment were to be the penalty inflicted on any parent or parents refusing to send their children. The next day after the edict, myself and my late colleague were sent for from our school by the Governor (which was on the 10th of January, 1872); so we appeared. After paying the honour that was due to him, he said to us, "Where are you from?" We replied, "Why did you undertake to conduct that school? It is for that you are brought before me, and I think you ought to be banished from this island for so doing." We then cogently replied; after which he sent us over to the Judge, and his Honour, after a day's investigation, acquitted us, as no fault was found in us. Now, let me ask, where was "Progress" at this time? Why did not he show his love of progress by going to the Governor and advocating on behalf of the school? As our school hours were all taken, our superintendent arranged with the people to hold our school one hour very early in the morning and another at night, which was agreed upon, but was altered last year by a kind Governor, who saw the difficulty of the children getting any education under such arrangement. Just imagine children from four years going to the English school early in the morning for an hour, after which they were to go home and take their breakfast; after breakfast, away to the Spanish school. At twelve o'clock they were to go home for dinner, and at two to return again to school until five, after which they went home for supper and to attend night school. Surely it was too much for the children, and the present arrangement is that an equal share of the day be granted to both schools. Could the public expect the same progress during these interferences as when there was no other school and we had the whole day? I pause for a reply. However, we are thankful to the Governor who last year made the present arrangement, for "a half-loaf," we believe, "is better than none." Dear Mr. Editor, not to trespass longer on your time and space, I must conclude by telling "Progress" that I have not only been a well-known pupil and monitor in the Government Boys' School (Freetown, Sierra Leone), but had been with the Rev. R. W. Hartshorn, M.A. (of blessed memory), for about three years; and so long as my ink-jug is not dried, nor my pen spoiled, he can write anything he likes against me; only, I will not after this answer his anonymous letters. — I am, Sir, yours, &c.,'}, {'id': 2978, 'article_title': "Public Demonstrations at the Cape of Good Hope in Support of Lord Carnarvon's Recommendations", 'full_section_title': "Public Demonstrations at the Cape of Good Hope in Support of Lord Carnarvon's Recommendations", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1875#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_11_1875', 'content': '**PUBLIC DEMONSTRATIONS AT THE CAPE OF GOOD HOPE IN SUPPORT OF LORD CARNARVON'S RECOMMENDATIONS.**

**PLYMOUTH, Oct. 19.**—The Union Company's Royal mail steamer Asiatic arrived here to-day. She brings advices from Cape Town to the 25th Sept. The *South African Mail* says: "The country is unanimously in favour of the Conference, and so great is the indignation of the colonists against the Cape Government that even if it were now to accede to sending representatives to the Conference it is doubtful whether the Parliament would agree to the Ministry retaining office."

Mr. Froude had a princely reception at Graham's Town. A large cavalcade went out to meet and escort him. He was received with a salute of twenty-four guns at the entrance of the town, and some 5,000 people assembled to meet him. An address was presented, and Mr. Froude's path was strewn with flowers by little girls prettily dressed. There was a grand banquet in his honour the night following, and the morning after he returned to Port Elizabeth.

The Honourable Commissioner of Public Works, Mr. Merriman, had opened the first stage of the Midland Railway. It was expected that his presence in the East, with the opening of this new work, would greatly strengthen the hands of the Government. All the arrangements were reported as admirable. Mr. Merriman thought it a fitting opportunity to discuss the great question of the day—Confederation—and to defend the Cape Government. The speech was made at a luncheon at which 400 persons were present.

The *Star*, describing this affair, says: "The Molteno Ministry is doomed. Mr. Merriman in the course of his speech called Mr. Froude a 'foreign agitator,' and denounced the Queen's Government as a 'foreign one.' Mr. Chabaud denounced Mr. Merriman in unmeasured terms, and said he had insulted Her Majesty the Queen, Earl Carnarvon, their distinguished visitor, and the people of Port Elizabeth. He then left the room, calling upon Port Elizabeth to follow, which most of the leading merchants and inhabitants did, and were continuing to do when the door was closed upon them. Mr. Paterson rebuked Mr. Merriman, and said that his indiscretion on that occasion proved his utter unfitness for office. The Chairman, after repeated efforts to get a hearing for him, and finding it impossible, led the Commissioner off by the back-door, and veritably broke up the assembly. The presence of numerous ladies is supposed to have alone prevented the prompt expulsion of the Commissioner by force by an insulted and indignant people.'}, {'id': 3516, 'article_title': 'Concessions to the Horrible Fetish Priests by the Acting Administrator of Lagos', 'full_section_title': 'Concessions to the Horrible Fetish Priests by the Acting Administrator of Lagos', 'last_edit_date': '12-18-1877', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1878#article-11', 'issue_date': '01_02_1878', 'content': 'Sir,—Our worthy friend, Governor Dumaresq, has returned from England, and has since been placed once more on the administrative throne. I am sorry to have again to complain of him, but you shall judge whether I have not just grounds for doing so.

A few weeks ago, a deputation of the Fetish priests from Badagry, under the patronage of that favoured native, Taiwo, waited on him, requesting him to grant them liberty to rebuild their Fetish-house at Badagry, as well as to re-establish the rude Fetish customs of confining marriageable girls, against their will, in the Fetish-house for a term of not less than one year; a system which was put an end to six or seven years ago, through the indefatigable, earnest labours of the Rev. Samuel Pearse and Commandant Tickell. Acting Administrator Dumaresq, who is not at all ignorant of the evil effects that will be produced by the re-establishment of the Fetish customs, and the great barrier it will prove in the way of Gospel progress at Badagry, granted their ungodly request without the least hesitation.'}, {'id': 3594, 'article_title': 'SHERBRO’ AFFAIRS—A GOVERNOR’S INCAPACITY.', 'full_section_title': 'SHERBRO’ AFFAIRS—A GOVERNOR’S INCAPACITY.', 'last_edit_date': '03-27-1878', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1878#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_05_1878', 'content': 'Sir,—A trader in the Boom River with whom I have business relations has sent me the inclosed letter, with a request that I would forward the same to you for publication.

I can indorse, from personal knowledge, the statements of “A Boom Trader.” I know that information of Cannagbo’s marauding expedition was in the hands of the Executive at Freetown on Feb. 23, yet it was the 24th March before Governor Rowe started for Sherbro’, notwithstanding the repeated urgent appeals for help and protection which were reaching him almost daily; and even then he went to Sherbro’, not so much to quell the disturbances in the Boom as to investigate a matter which has been pending many months, to the prejudice and injury of a meritorious officer, who has been kept all this time in suspense, because Governor Rowe deemed it more urgent and necessary to remain in Freetown, interfering in the pettiest details of every department, all of which are now so utterly disorganized by his system of meddling and muddling, that the heads of these departments, whose functions and responsibilities have been usurped or overruled by the Governor, scarcely know the state of affairs in their respective offices; and the Governor himself, who wishes to take everything into his own hands and do everything himself, knows still less; so that nothing is done at all, and confusion reigns supreme, the official business of the colony having come to a complete dead-lock.

The Governor has become so unpopular, so intensely detested and despised, that his name is execrated by high and low, and his exit from the settlement will be a matter of universal rejoicing; indeed, he will be fortunate if his embarkation be not attended with even worse hissings and hootings than those which greeted the departure of a former Governor some twenty-five years ago. This will be a sorry termination of the administration of one who has boasted that he “was born to be a ruler of men”! Could the proceedings of Governor Rowe during a single week be seen by the Secretary of State, the recall of such a person to fill the post he now holds, to the prejudice of the prestige of the British nation in these regions, and to the injury of trade, would be instantaneous.

I can corroborate the statement of the nature of Governor Rowe’s late illness, which would be confirmed on reference to the medical men of the place; in fact, in no other way can we, that charitable construction we desire on his erratic proceedings. It is, therefore, evident that Governor Rowe is not at present the right man in the right place, especially seeing the state of trade, and of our relations with surrounding tribes and with our French neighbours. We want a chief of the Executive fully possessing *mens sana in corpore sano*.'}, {'id': 3594, 'article_title': 'SHERBRO’ AFFAIRS—A GOVERNOR’S INCAPACITY.', 'full_section_title': 'SHERBRO’ AFFAIRS—A GOVERNOR’S INCAPACITY.', 'last_edit_date': '03-27-1878', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1878#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_05_1878', 'content': 'The neglect of Governor Rowe to call together his Executive Council in order to deliberate on matters of importance, is another subject of unfavourable comment; in fact, in every way Governor Rowe seeks to distinguish his rule by his arbitrary and autocratic conduct, and thus disappoint the expecta- tions formed during his tenure of office as Lieutenant-Governor. How long this state of things can last I know not, but surely the Secretary of State will soon interfere, and that before the two innocent British subjects, murdered in the Boom, who owe their deaths to criminal supineness and neglect, are joined in the other world by many more victims.—Yours, &c.,'}, {'id': 3598, 'article_title': 'Important Memorial from Sierra Leone', 'full_section_title': 'Important Memorial from Sierra Leone', 'last_edit_date': '06-12-1878', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1878#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_07_1878', 'content': '8. His Excellency continued, in the same meeting, to make various remarks, and after speaking again to the Sierra Leone people—one of whom, called William Chapman, he, in a loud and angry voice, called "you brute, you beast; you beast, you brute," because the said Mr. Chapman was under the necessity to rise to go into the yard whilst his Excellency was speaking—his Excellency turned to the said Pa Sorie Conditto and addressed him in effect as follows:—

"Sorie Conditto, you see these Sierra Leone people who come to your country, they are not better than you. You are better than they. My ancestors brought the fathers and mothers of the Sierra Leone people in slave-ships where they were packed as you do your sheep and goats in your pens. You could not distinguish a man from a woman among them. They were landed on the beach at Sierra Leone from the slave-ships, and they had not even a piece of cloth around their waist. They have no country. This country is yours. If it were not for my Government protecting them, you the Timmannees, as well as the Mendis, could go to Sierra Leone and drive them from there into the river in a day. If any of the Sierra Leone people disobey your law in future, you must take hold of him, punish him severely, and put his foot in stocks, and then send him to me in Sierra Leone, and I shall know how to punish him further."

9. As his Excellency said this, the said Henry Cline turned to the Sierra Leone people, and said, "You all hear what the Governor says."

10. In the said meeting his Excellency also, amongst other things, said that Port Lokkoh was out of the British jurisdiction, and that the people of the country could drive the Sierra Leone traders away from thence, and that those traders should go to Kissy-road and Kroo Town-road, in Freetown, to move about there.

11. And I, the said Samuel Argentine Roberts, for myself, further solemnly and sincerely declare that on the landing of his Excellency at Port Lokkoh, on the 31st of March last, I procured for his Excellency's European clerks rooms in my house to stay in. His Excellency himself occupied a house about a yard distant from mine. I then employed some men to go and fetch water for his Excellency's bath, and after the people had gone to fetch the water, the said William John Davies came into the yard to pay his respects to his Excellency.

12. And we, the said Samuel Argentine Roberts and William John Davies, severally, for ourselves further solemnly and sincerely declare that, as soon as the said William John Davies entered the yard, his Excellency walked up to him, and said, in effect, "Mr. Gentleman, what are you doing here? You stand up now as a lord, doing nothing, whilst I, the Governor, am suffering, and get no water to bathe myself. You had better go off now, else I'll have you taken in charge." The said William John Davies merely answered that he had gone to pay his respects to his Excellency, and departed.'}, {'id': 4033, 'article_title': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'full_section_title': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'last_edit_date': '03-26-1880', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1880#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_09_1880', 'content': "Lagos, March 26th.  
(Continued from our June Number.)

The plan for the first year worked on successfully. An amount of about £421 or more was raised; one-third of the amount of course, goes to the School Board Fund, and after defraying all necessary expenses in all the churches, there was a balance of about £200 or more, which is now in the hands of the Treasurer as a reserve fund to begin the Native Pastorate. In the midst of this never yet heard of success at Abeokuta, the Bishop arrived, questioned Johnson how many slaves he had, and the native agents under his superintendence—he having met with them previous to the arrival of the Bishop, and devised plans by which they are to gradually impress on the minds of the converts the evil of holding their fellow-creatures as property, and to be disposed of at any time of need; and they did not tell him they had any. They, themselves, boldly answered the Bishop that they had none. The next day the Bishop met with the native agents, and asked them one by one, and, to Johnson's shame and surprise, they confessed to the Bishop that they had slaves and the number each one of them had. Every civilized man can picture the position in which Johnson now stands to the Bishop and the Parent Committee. A meeting was held to receive the Bishop; the Bishop, in addressing the people, used some phrases, but not with any evil intention. He said that the people must have been very rich, and have plenty of money, else they would not have neglected asking him for his annual subscription towards the School Board Fund. The people at once willingly misconstrued the Bishop's meaning, and said, Is it because they are rich they should be made to pay five strings for class, and two and a-half strings subscription towards the School Board Fund, when the Bishop, who has been helping them, is still willing to help them? Why should they, then, tax themselves (and perhaps the Bishop only gives 1l. or 2l. paid annually)? The Bishop also spoke on the subject of domestic slavery, which grieved the people very much, and they wished to know the party who exposed them to the Bishop. The native agents having suspected Johnson to be the doer, spoke their minds to the members. After this, the people would not pay their class fees, nor the subscription towards the School Board Fund. Johnson, not knowing the ill feelings of the native agents and members against him, held on fast for payment, and gave orders to the native agents to take off the names of the non-paying members from the class list."}]
