[{'document_title': 'LETTERS TO THE EDITOR', 'section_title': '', 'content': '(The Editor cannot hold himself responsible for the opinions of his correspondents.)*

---

### DISSATISFACTION AMONG THE NATIVES IN LAGOS.

**TO THE EDITOR OF THE "AFRICAN TIMES."**

December 18, 1884.

Sir,—Your journal being the representative organ in Europe for the West Coast of Africa, we feel compelled to state, for the information of the authorities in Downing-street and the public generally, that up to the embarkation in August last of Commander Rumsey, the Deputy Governor of Lagos, for Europe, the town was quiet; but since then there has been general dissatisfaction, owing to several "acts" of the present Administration, whose advisers have managed to create dissensions, and to set class against class. Acting under cover of authority, respectable natives have been arrested on pain of being locked up in the guard-room of the Houssas, or seized and deported to St. Helena, without any real cause, while the accused is kept ignorant of his offence. Such, Sir, are the acts of certain officials (European and native) in Lagos, who design to gain popularity, honour, and promotion by misrepresentations. The administrations of Sir Samuel Rowe, Lieut.-Governor Griffith, Captain Moloney, and Captain Rumsey are disparaged by these men. We ask, can a servant be greater than his master? These men say they know Lagos and Africa more than any other person. But what knowledge can be looked for from men whose previous lives have been all unfitted for such duties as they now have to perform? It is honourable to rise from humble positions; yet the mind should be humble; and when uncultivated, to give such persons positions is dangerous. Is it customary for the Premier of England, or the Secretary of State for the Colonies, to send a policeman from their official residence in Downing-street to arrest any of the members of the Opposition simply on the report that they speak against the Government, and on their arrival in Downing-street to abuse and insult them, and ultimately send them to prison forthwith, or exile to Canada, saying that the official powers are extraordinary and unlimited? We ask, is this possible? and would such action show a cultivated mind and civility? It is an open secret in Lagos that such treatment is by no means uncommon here.

It is a blessing that we are under a Governor-in-Chief who is well able to check the ambitious views of his subordinates.

Is it usual for the Premier of England or Governor of a colony to send a superintendent of police with one or two constables to proclaim, without law or ordinance, that no provisions are to be sold to a neighbouring friendly country; and if such country retaliate by stopping its own supply, then for the sovereign of the friendly country to be accused as a barbarous and atrocious king?—Your obedient servants,

**LAGOSIANS.**', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1885#article-28', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.727, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRUE STATEMENTS OF THE CAUSE OF LAGOS DISASTERS.—No. II.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Dear Sir,—After perusing the several articles in the English papers (especially the _Manchester Courier_) on the affairs of Lagos, I feel that it is only fair and just to Governor Pope Hennessy that I should relate in your valuable columns a brief history of the cause of differences between the Lagos Government and the Egbas and Ijebus which have caused them to close their trade against Lagos up to this time; and being an African and knowing my countrymen, I think you will agree with me that my statements claim more credence than any which Mr. Charles Leigh Clare (who only wrote from hearsay, and has never been in Lagos) has or can make. Nothing can be more untrue than Mr. Clare's assertion in the _Manchester Courier_ that the roads for trade were closed in consequence of the policy of Governor Hennessy, and I am glad to find that it has been contradicted in the same paper as well as in the _African Times_.

Now, Mr. Editor, it seems that Captain Glover and his friends are trying to make the British public believe that the Egbas and Ijebus are antagonistic to British presence in Lagos on account of the Slave question, and they go on to argue that if Governor Hennessy's policy was good, why have not the roads been open to trade since June, 1872, to the present time? They forget the fact that a wound which can be inflicted in a moment cannot be healed for a long time. I state it as an indisputable fact which can bear any test of investigation, that Captain Glover, during the period of his administration of the government of this settlement (from 1863 to 1872), managed to inflict such serious political wounds on the minds of the Egbas and Ijebus, that it is surprising he and his friends should expect those wounds to be healed in the very short time in which Governor Hennessy tried to heal them. Happily for Lagos Lord Kimberley sent out Governor Hennessy at the time he did; otherwise I cannot say how serious the state of things in Lagos would have become. Party spirit and tribal feelings were running so high at the time, that it is questionable whether the authorities would have been able to prevent one of the most bitter and destructive civil wars from breaking out within this settlement, beginning in the town of Lagos itself.", 'last_edit_date': '1873-03-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_04_1873#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.724, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Official Correspondence on the Affairs of Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'COPY OF LETTER TO THE EARL OF KIMBERLY ON LAGOS AFFAIRS.**

_African Times Office, 121, Fleet-street, Dec. 16, 1871._

My Lord,—I deeply regret that the contents of letters I have received during the present month, and especially by the Roquelle, to hand this day, should have been such as to place me under the necessity of addressing your lordship on the subject of the state of affairs in Lagos.

All my correspondents in Lagos, even those who have been among the most staunch supporters of the present Administrator, are unanimous in representing the anxiety and apprehension that exist there at present, caused by a seeming tendency on the part of the Executive to foment troubles in the interior countries, and interfere unjustifiably and dangerously with contiguous territories and peoples.

On the 11th of September last, the Administrator caused the Legislative Council to pass through all its three stages "An Ordinance to authorise the Administrator to prohibit the export of arms and other munitions of war from Lagos in certain cases." Since that time there has been a restlessness on the part of the Executive, which has been unmitigatedly evil in its tendency. He is stated to have allowed a petition to be got up by certain dependents of the Government, calling upon him to annex Porto Novo and its territories. By sundry unnecessary and threatening voyages in the colonial steamer, attended by a force of Houssas, &c., he has given colour to the belief that he has such plans in contemplation; and considering what took place in the years 1864-1867, it is not surprising that merchants and traders, the whole of whose property would be imperilled and destroyed by a renewal of the overt and secret acts of policy then committed, should even give credit to the report of their Administrator having allowed his feelings of hostility against the Egba nations so far to prevail with him over all just, honourable, humane, and politic considerations, as to induce him privately to instigate the Kings of Dahomey and Ibadan conjointly to attack, and if possible destroy Abeokuta during the present dry season.

The proper policy of Lagos, as a great emporium of trade for extensive inland countries, must manifestly be to cultivate amicable relations with all of them, and scrupulously to abstain from everything that could give rise to suspicions of hostile feelings or intentions as regards any of them. The', 'last_edit_date': '1872-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1872#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.734, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS AFFAIRS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We cannot say what may be the news now on its way to England from Lagos. We cannot defer the preparations for our paper until the day of its publication, and are therefore under the necessity of commenting on what is known to us at the time we write. We hope, and have reason to believe, that before our present number goes to press, we shall have received the long desired intelligence of the difficulties with Egbas, Jebus, and others being all removed; and of the long desolate markets of Lagos overflowing with produce. We have not any such news at present; but what we have, affords additional proof of the heavy responsibility that rests upon all concerned in the Government of a trading British settlement or colony, when they, through ignorance or malice, pursue a course which is calculated to bring on a commercial paralysis. By inexcusable ignorance on the part of a Secretary of State, and the very wantonness of official evil on the part of an Administrator, the trade and commerce of Lagos was arrested in its course on the 18th of March last. The authorities of the native interior countries from which Lagos draws its commercial supplies, had been goaded by repeated and incessant insults and wrongs, into a condition of mind which led them to refuse all further trading intercourse, until the official author of those insults and wrongs should be removed from the office which gave him power thus to outrage them and their people. At the first glance it would have seemed as if trade would be immediately resumed, from the moment such removal were made, and the obnoxious measures repealed and abolished; and we must confess that, although our knowledge of African thought and action is derived from the varied experience of many years, we fell into the error of believing that such would be the case in this instance. We thought the Egba authorities and the King of Jebu, knowing as they did that the grievances of which they had so much reason to complain were the unhealthy spawn of one diseased official mind alone—that the quarrel really was between them and the late Administrator of Lagos only, and not really between them and Great Britain, would have hastened to show their satisfaction at the removal of their official enemy from his post and power, and have at once set free the fettered hands of commerce. It has not been so. Captain Glover was sent away from Lagos by Mr. Pope Hennessey, on the 15th June—and all obnoxious decrees, irritating and injurious to the Egbas and others, were at the same time repealed; but yet, up to the 6th August at least, the Egbas and Jebus had not removed their interdict on trade. The venom was still rankling in the veins of those who had been stung, and a sense of offended dignity prevented the due consideration of the evils resulting to their own subjects and territories, as well as to Lagos and its traders, from the prohibition to export that produce on which the wealth and progress of both the one and the other depend. Lagos and its native traders and merchants especially have been thus doomed to a prolonged continuance of those evils to which we briefly alluded in our last; and in the paralysis of all available means for paying debts and obligations, the law—British law—has handed the unfortunate fish to the greedy cormorants who are ever ready to seek their unjust gains among the necessities of their fellow-men. British officials spear the fish—British magistrates net them—and British cormorants devour them. We feel it to be our duty, therefore, to repeat the protest we made in our last, against the uninterrupted action of commercial law, through British legal authorities and tribunals, at periods when the British governing power has chosen for its own ends, or in its own ignorance or wickedness, to cut off from the trading masses of the community, those means by which alone they could be enabled to meet their commercial engagements. During the perturbation caused by the late French and German war—during the siege of Paris, and the reign of the Commune, and for some time after, no creditor was allowed to put the machinery of law at work in France, for the enforcement of civil contracts, to despoil and ruin his fellow-citizen. And thus it ought to have been in Lagos during this suspension of trade, which resulted entirely from acts of Government, and not from any acts or errors of individual traders, or from any cause which any one individual of the trading community, or the whole body of them combined, could suspend or control. They did what they could by remonstrance, by petition, by communication to the Home authorities, and through the African Times; and having done this, they are none of them morally, however they may be made legally, responsible for the results against which they petitioned and remonstrated. We do not need any spirit to come from the other world to tell us that these remarks of ours will not produce the effects they ought to produce. The duty of a public writer is not limited by the extent of his power to procure the justice to which he may establish a claim. It is his duty to hold aloft the lamp of truth, and leave the results of his so doing to others. It is at least a consolation to victims, if the light thus diffused, shall enable every observer to see that the wheels which are crushing the poor victims of commercial misgovernment, are official ones; that they have not voluntarily thrown themselves under them with suicidal intent, but have been thrust under them by an erring Secretary of State, and the malicious wantonness of official power in his delegate, to whom the victim was bound to yield unresistingly. The light thus diffused may, and often does, serve also to prevent the recurrence of errors and wickedness of a similar kind, and thus gradually helps on changes which conduce to an enlarged general security against the errors and aberration of constituted authorities.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1872#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.725, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the present time, from all parts of the West African coast, we have reports of troubles and disturbances, which must hamper trade and retard the commercial and civilising development of that part of the Dark Continent. For some months now the trade of Lagos has been blocked by the closing of the roads which, running through the district inhabited by the Jebu and Egba tribes, connect that port with the interior; but we are pleased to learn, from the latest telegrams received, that the careful and earnest steps that are being taken by the authorities to secure the opening of these trade routes, have not been without their moral effect upon the tribes implicated, for they are already making overtures of peace and reconciliation. It is much to be hoped that this is the case, for at the present time trade needs fostering on the West Coast more than perhaps ever before, and this object can only be attained by the cheerful co-operation of all interested in its maintenance. The British administration in West Africa has been by no means free from faults in the past; and these faults have born their natural fruit. The secret of good Colonial government would seem to consist in interfering as little as possible with Native customs and prejudices, but at the same time making it thoroughly understood that laws and ordinances must be respected. Now that the dispute with the Jebus and Egbas would seem to be in a fair way of settlement, it affords an opportunity to the Governor of Lagos to insure that, though these tribes are to be treated fairly and with patience, they must quite understand that any infraction of the engagements now or subsequently undertaken by them, will be visited most severely upon the offenders.

But the troubles in this part of the world are by no means confined to the British. It appears that the French have been forced into a war with Dahomey, the only...

[MAY 2, 1892.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.746, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Official Correspondence on the Affairs of Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'My Lord,—I had the honour to address your lordship a second time on the state of affairs at Lagos, under date December 30, 1871, and regret to find that my duty again compels me to bring that state of affairs under your lordship's notice.

By the steam-ship Congo, which arrived in Liverpool on the 29th ultimo, I have received, among other letters from Lagos, one from a merchant very largely engaged in the commerce of that place, who writes as follows:—

"There have been great and wonderful changes in the policy of our Government during the last few months. At present it appears as if a cloud were gathering, that must soon burst with great violence upon our surrounding neighbours and ourselves; and this for no cause whatever. The aspect of our present policy can only be compared to that of 1864. The stoppage of the roads from Abeokuta had almost taken place a fortnight ago, had it not been for some of the merchants there who remonstrated with the chiefs, that they should first ask for an explanation from our Governor of certain policy which they regard as in great opposition to them, while it serves to suit the purposes of other nations. There is no end of ups and downs with us, and sending to and fro, as a wild lion seeking for a prey. In fact we are looking very anxiously to see what will be the issue of our uncalled-for policy. Surely it will be prevented being any other than that the mountain which laboured and brought forth a mouse."

I will not trouble your lordship with any comment on the above, except that it places anew and in a very strong light the necessity of some adequate interference by your lordship, to put an end to those aberrations of the Lagos Executive, which are paving the way for most deplorable results.—I have the honour to remain, my Lord, yours very respectfully,

F. FITZGERALD,  
(11 Years Editor of the African Times.)  
To the Right Hon. the Earl of Kimberley, K.G., &c., &c., Colonial-office.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1872#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.72, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS AFFAIRS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Again our hopes have been disappointed. Another month, with the year 1873 also close upon us, without any news of the actual re-opening of trade at Lagos. Month after month brings us a repetition of the same hopes and beliefs—a repetition of the same disappointments. Where is all this to end? When are the reasonable hopes of the merchant and trader, based on an estimate of human wants and desires, to be fulfilled? Alas! we know not. Had the British policy at Lagos been a reasonable one, the native people around would have been encouraged, long ere this, to appoint someone to represent them in England—to make known their complaints and desires, and to seek satisfaction for them—instead of resorting to the barbarous system of cutting off communications, and annihilating trade, to the loss and inconvenience of their own people, as well as those of the Government with which they disagree. But, unfortunately, the British Executive in Lagos has been accustomed to represent itself to the native countries around as so immediately deriving its power from the Queen of Great Britain, and so essentially reflecting the feelings and views of the Queen respecting them, that any attempt on their part to appeal against its decisions and acts would be altogether vain and fruitless. Hence it has come to pass that, instead of referring to the British Government in England against the injurious acts and hostile policy, and aggrandising encroachments, of the local British authority, they have, to the great injury of themselves as well as of the traders of Lagos, met the injurious acts of the Lagos Executive with reprisals, and closed their roads and markets against us. What is to be done under these circumstances? The British Government either desire territorial aggrandisement for the Colony of Lagos, or they do not. They either wish that Lagos should be a territorially expanding colony, with all the necessary commitments as regards Imperial expenditure, or they do not. If they do not, nothing can be more easy than to give such assurances, and make such changes, as shall convince the Egbas and Jebus that there is not only no desire on the part of the British Government that Lagos should usurp power and dominion over them, and wrest from them their territory, but that they are entirely opposed thereto, and look upon Lagos solely as a commercial colony, the only conquests of which are to be those of trade and commerce—a promotion of the material development of their countries, and the spread of civiliza...', 'last_edit_date': '1872-12-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_12_1872#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.741, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ABEOKUTA AND LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The letter we have now published (p. 36) on "What Caused the Heathen Uprising in Abeokuta on Sunday, October 13, 1867," brings the whole question of the unsettled and most unsatisfactory state of relations between Lagos and Abeokuta again prominently before us. The sale and gift of lands at Ebute Meta by the Lagos Government, constituting as this does an absolute claim and assumption of British authority over that portion of the main land, is a measure of such extreme importance as bearing upon the present and future relations between the British colony of Lagos and the native government of Abeokuta, that nothing short of the most imperious necessity, and the most indisputable and indefeasible claim, can possibly justify such proceedings. There is no portion of the West Coast at which the development of productive resources and the increase of commerce, may be so rapid as in the Abeokuta Territories (with Yoruba generally) and Lagos, provided there be a constantly good and friendly understanding and amicable relations between Lagos and Abeokuta. But for this it is essential that nothing should be done on the part of the Island Government to wound the just susceptibilities, or aggravate the unfortunate distrust of the Abeokutans, as regards British encroachment. The progress of Christian civilisation and material development in the Yoruba countries and primarily among the Aku people, and the increase of the trade of Lagos, are desired results necessarily bound up together and inseparably united. It is not for the permanent mercantile interests of Lagos that she should be mixed up with the wars and disputes of the interior, except as a great civilised pacificator—as the representative of British Christian civilisation acting for the amelioration of adjacent heathen lands. But if Lagos holds absolute possession on the main land, she can scarcely fail to be involved in such native wars and disputes; and it must be expected that questions will continually arise to disturb the friendly intercourse of Lagos with the interior. We regard this matter of the present and future relations of Lagos with the main-land people, and especially with Abeokuta, as one of such very great importance, that we feel it to be our duty to solicit for it the prompt and especial attention of the Governor-in-Chief. Among the gross neglects of duty of Governor Blackall we look upon his conduct as regards this important matter, as one of the most serious, and at the same time, most irritating to native susceptibilities and suspicions. We see with pleasure that the Governor of Lagos has been lately invited to Sierra Leone by the Governor-in-Chief; doubtless for those explanations as regards the Lagos Government which could scarcely be fully given without a personal interview; and as the facts, real or supposed, as viewed by the local Lagos Executive, and the views of that Executive, will now have been brought under the keen and impartial mental scrutiny of Sir Arthur Kennedy, we look forward with hope and confidence to some action of the Governor-in-Chief, that shall lead to a speedy placing of the relations of Lagos with Abeokuta, and *vice versa*, on a just and friendly footing, such as will tend to the permanent reciprocal advantage of the inhabitants of the British colony and of the adjacent native territories.', 'last_edit_date': '1868-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.727, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS AND THE NEIGHBOURING COUNTRIES', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There can be no prosperity and increase of legitimate trade without peace. If trade languishes or is violently disturbed the public revenues must suffer, and with a deficiency of revenue, public improvements, however necessary or indispensable, must be postponed. Such contingencies are serious ones for an infant island colony like Lagos, the prosperity and increase of whose commerce depend entirely on the demand and supply of exchangeable commodities on the neighbouring mainland. Since it became a possession of the British Crown, Lagos has undergone great commercial vicissitudes, and much trading disaster has occurred through the unsettled or hostile relations of the colony with the Egba countries. We had hoped that this was entirely of the past—that the Lagos Executive had so far gained its point with the mainland people, that it could devote itself entirely to the fostering of trade and commerce and the employment of the increasing revenues consequent on a state of peace, to local improvements such as it befits a civilized Government to make in Africa, and to the education of the people so as to fit them for those free institutions to which they are destined. It is therefore with very great anxiety that we hear of rumours at Lagos of a meddling policy that threatens to renew the commercial disasters of the colony. We try to hope that the rumours are unfounded, and that the Administrator will not in any way justify the fears entertained of him. A contrary course will incline all reflecting and prudent men to believe that there is in him some inherent defect of character, which, though it might not unfit him for naval command or internal exploration, does really incapacitate him for the duties of a peaceable governor.', 'last_edit_date': '1867-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1867#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.734, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFFAIRS IN LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'One would naturally have expected that some British official from Lagos would have visited Abeokuta and seen its rulers, or that a resident would have been appointed; but, although it is only seventy miles from Lagos, and can be reached by road or river in three or four days, no British official of any standing, and, I believe, no British official at all, has visited the place for at least twenty years.

It seems incredible that a walled town with a population estimated at from 60,000 to 100,000, and contributing over £20,000 a year to the revenue of Lagos should be utterly unknown, so far as personal inspection goes, to any British official.

Fear of danger or of offending the Egba authorities cannot be the cause of this neglect; if a French officer can go and make a treaty, a British officer might at least venture to do the same.

I think the neglect must be attributed to "the system," that intangible scapegoat of British officialdom, and the sooner it is mended the better.

A travelling commissioner should be appointed, who could visit not only Abeokuta, but Ibadan, Oyo, and Ilorin, and, generally speaking, the countries between the sea and the Niger as far north and west as Boosa.

Indifference as to the interior, followed by French encroachments from behind, has destroyed all possibility of expansion, and has greatly curtailed the revenues of our colonies of Gambia and Sierra Leone.

It is to be hoped that the same fate will not overtake Lagos. Insignificant and little known as this colony is, the manufactures it imports, and the vessels employed in its commerce, are the means of supplying a living to at least 20,000 of our fellow-countrymen.

Surely this is a sufficient reason for looking after our interests, especially as our doing so can only be productive of good to the interior tribes.

Comparisons are often useful, and if the neighbouring German colonies of Togoland and Cameroons can send well-equipped expeditions into the interior and France can spend £4,000 a-year in Porto Novo, from which she has never drawn a penny, surely Lagos can send a commissioner to cultivate friendly relations with the people who, by consuming our manufactures, supply its revenue.

Without the interior, Lagos is worthless; with it there is the prospect of permanent peace in the interior, and, consequently, a great increase in trade and in the well-being of the inhabitants.—I am, Sir, your obedient servant,', 'last_edit_date': '1889-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1889#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.76, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE RELATIONS OF LAGOS WITH ABEOKUTA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are not at all satisfied with what is taking place at Lagos. We have never embarrassed the actual local colonial government by a severe examination of, or strictures upon its acts and ordinances. We have never done more than gently hint, during the reign of the present Governor, that there were some of them we found it difficult to reconcile, to understand, or to approve, without explanations for which we sought in vain. But in the interests of African civilization, of the African people, of legitimate commerce, and therefore of Lagos itself, this sort of indulgence cannot be indefinitely extended. We have given the local government carte blanche for a long period—perhaps for too long a one. The late ordinance issued there makes us feel very strongly that this is the case. It is about the first time in the history and career of our colonies that we have heard, or read, or known of the fact of being a British subject constituting a disqualification for carrying on trade beyond the limits of the colony. This seems to us a monstrous doctrine, or principle, or whatever it may seem fit to his Excellency to designate it. An export duty of two and a-half per cent. on British and other goods sent from Lagos for Abeokuta! and no British merchant shall be engaged in the trade!! We shall wait the arrival of next month's mail with no little impatience.

Meanwhile we insert two letters from Abeokuta which come to us with the facts they enumerate seemingly so well authenticated, that we had really no choice left about publishing them. If—we say if—the facts are really as therein stated—if there be "nothing extenuate, nor aught set down in malice," we were indeed justified in those doubts we expressed about the raising of the siege of Ikorodu, that there was something not altogether right; not altogether clear and honourable, in the dealings of the Lagos Executive with the Egbas, among whose hosts such havoc had been committed by rockets, rifles, and bayonets. The importance of Abeokuta as regards the spread of civilization, if in constant friendly alliance with Lagos and in peaceful relations with its African neighbours, is indisputable; and we cannot approve (leaving the past, reopened by the letters we have inserted, for the present unjudged) of any measures that tend to prolong the epoch of alienation after the Abeokuta authorities have made—as it seems to us that they have made—every reasonable concession to Lagos demands.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1865#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.722, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Lagos and its Affairs—Captain Strachan and Captain Glover', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We shall be sorry indeed to find that the Colonial-office has made another mistake in the appointment of Captain Strachan to the Administratorship of Lagos. That settlement has been so great a sufferer through official mismanagement, and so many innocent persons have, as a consequence, been wholly or in part ruined, with a serious loss thereby of British capital, that the wounds require soothing by anodynes, not irritating by caustic. During the interview of the commercial deputation with Earl Kimberley in May last, his lordship spoke so confidently as to the merits of Captain Strachan, who might be regarded "as almost a civilian," that we expected to hear of a courteous, confidence-inspiring Administrator installed in his person within the walls of the Government-house at Lagos. We regret, however, that it should be our duty to state that the first impressions at Lagos have not been favourable as regards the new Administrator. If the description came to us from one quarter only, we should have taken no public notice of it; but it comes to us from several and distinct ones; and what we gather is, that his tone is not at all a soothing one; his bearing is lofty, for Africa, and frightens even Europeans away from Government-house. We cannot help feeling that this is a bad beginning. His predecessor, Mr. Berkeley, the present Governor-in-Chief of the West Coast Settlements, gained golden opinions of all in Lagos; he was beloved there; and we never heard that the public service was thereby injured, or the Queen's government thereby lowered in the estimation of Europeans or natives. It would be, indeed, lamentable should Colonel Strachan undo what Mr. Berkeley effected; nor do we hesitate to say that such a result would put an end at once and for ever to the system of appointing naval and military men as Administrators of commercial settlements—a system which was, with so much reason, denounced by the deputation, to whose interview with Earl Kimberley we have before alluded.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-11-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_11_1873#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.743, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COPY OF THE REPORT OF COL. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Unfortunately, however, on the whole length of coast on which our eastern settlements are situated, there is no river capable of admitting a ship of any kind (indeed there is but one stream between Sierra Leone and Benin, a distance of 1,100 miles), and in the northern colonies of Sierra Leone and Gambia, both of which possess rivers, there is not the material for such a trade as is found at the oil rivers; their case must, therefore, be admitted to be an exceptional one, and, as such, to afford no ground for the objections which have been raised upon it to the retention of the settlements in their present form.

The idea of reducing the settlements to the condition of trading ports, with a consular authority to protect British interests, no doubt recommends itself to notice by the impression it creates that the expense, trouble, and inconvenience the settlements now entail would be thus altogether removed; but we are, fortunately, not without experience of the consequences to which such an arrangement would lead.

For ten years, from 1852 to 1861, the island of Lagos was the residence of European merchants, who carried on an extensive and remunerative trade, for the prosecution of which its position afforded considerable facilities, and which at the same time preserved it to a great extent from the aggression of neighbouring tribes. It was governed by its native king, who was placed on the throne, after the expulsion of the usurper, by the efforts of the British squadron, and was maintained in that position by the same power, and lastly it had the assistance, as British Consuls, of men of ability and local experience, who exerted themselves in every way to promote its prosperity and advancement. The result has been already detailed; after ten years of misrule, Her Majesty's Government, notwithstanding its reluctance to extend the British dependencies on the African coast, was compelled, in the interests of humanity, to take possession of Lagos, and make it a British settlement.

If such were the consequences of this experiment in a place like Lagos, possessing so many conditions favourable to its success, it can hardly be doubted what would follow an attempt to apply it to places like the Gambia and the Gold Coast, surrounded by powerful and warlike natives, who are now only kept in restraint by the knowledge that we possess the power to enforce submission to our authority.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.728, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Public Affairs in Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our latest advices state that the heavy cloud from the interior that seemed to be threatening mercantile operations in Lagos had happily dispersed. The change of rulers which took place some months ago in Ibadan had brought pacific results. All the efforts that had been made by certain influential persons in Lagos to stir up war in the interior had consequently failed, the Ibadas refusing to carry out the suggestions conveyed to them; their reply being that, neither alone nor in combination with the Dahomians, would they make war against the Egbas this dry season. They said that they and the Egbas are one family; also that they are neighbours; that they do not make war their trade. Commercial men in Lagos were finding great relief in this, although very greatly vexed at the either unmeaning or bad meaning (they were in doubt which) prohibition to export arms and ammunition from Lagos. Public opinion was very decided against this prohibition, the continuance of which, without any justifiable grounds, so far as could be perceived, was causing rumours of hostile intentions on the part of the Government against the King of Porto Novo, thus renewing anxiety and vexation among the trading community, who cannot imagine any good reason why Lagos should not be at peace and in friendship with all her neighbours, all of them being necessary to the proper supply of food and export produce in her markets.—Ed. A. T.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1872#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.726, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: British military operations and governance in Cape Coast were marked by incompetence and mistreatment, destabilizing local communities and exacerbating tensions.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide a comprehensive view of the claim that British military operations and governance in Cape Coast were marked by incompetence and mistreatment, leading to destabilization and increased tensions. The General History of Africa highlights British expansionist policies, such as those implemented by Smith, which deprived the Xhosa of their independence and led to the Anglo-Xhosa war of 1850-3. The imposition of white magistrates unfamiliar with local laws created grievances among the Xhosa, while the actions of the British Resident Warden in the Orange River Sovereignty, such as ignoring Moshoeshoe's territorial claims, exacerbated tensions and led to military conflicts. The British faced challenges in maintaining control, as seen in the Cape-Sotho War of 1880-1, where their efforts to disarm African states met with resistance. Additionally, the British administration's mishandling of economic issues, like the cocoa hold-ups in the Gold Coast, demonstrated a lack of understanding of local economic conditions, leading to unrest. The African Times articles further support this claim by detailing instances of mismanagement and abuse by British officials and military personnel, including violent attacks by soldiers from the West India Regiment on the local population, failure to maintain discipline among troops, and a corrupt and inefficient governance system. Reports of neglect in public health and sanitation, lack of effective communication with local authorities, and arbitrary fines on local chiefs contributed to unrest and dissatisfaction. Together, these sources illustrate a pattern of British incompetence and mistreatment, highlighting the negative impact on local communities and the exacerbation of tensions in the region.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides several details that align with the claim that British military operations and governance in Cape Coast were marked by incompetence and mistreatment, leading to destabilization and increased tensions. The text describes how British expansionist policies, such as those implemented by Smith, deprived the Xhosa of their independence and led to the Anglo-Xhosa war of 1850-3. The British imposed white magistrates who were unfamiliar with local laws, leading to grievances among the Xhosa. Additionally, the British Resident Warden's actions in the Orange River Sovereignty, such as ignoring Moshoeshoe's territorial claims and favoring smaller states, exacerbated tensions and led to military conflicts. The British also faced challenges in maintaining control, as seen in the Cape-Sotho War of 1880-1, where their efforts to disarm African states were met with resistance. Furthermore, the British administration's handling of economic issues, such as the cocoa hold-ups in the Gold Coast, demonstrated a lack of understanding and sensitivity to local economic conditions, leading to further unrest. These examples illustrate a pattern of British governance that often resulted in increased tensions and instability in the region, supporting the claim of incompetence and mistreatment.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that British military operations and governance in Cape Coast were marked by incompetence and mistreatment, which destabilized local communities and exacerbated tensions. The articles highlight numerous instances of mismanagement and abuse by British officials and military personnel. For example, there are reports of soldiers from the West India Regiment engaging in violent and indiscriminate attacks on the local population, including the murder of civilians and the destruction of property. The articles also describe the failure of British authorities to maintain discipline among troops, leading to mutinies and insubordination. Additionally, the governance system is criticized for being corrupt and inefficient, with officials accused of neglecting public health and sanitation, resulting in unsanitary conditions and potential health crises. The articles further mention the lack of effective communication and coordination between the British government and local authorities, as well as the imposition of arbitrary fines and exactions on local chiefs, which contributed to unrest and dissatisfaction. These details align with the claim of British incompetence and mistreatment, highlighting the negative impact on local communities and the exacerbation of tensions in the region.
topic2: Social and Political Tensions under Colonial Administrations
